Moreover, the three grades of worthies and ten stages all take the bodhi mind as their essence. The bodhi mind has three aspects:
First, the sincere mind, because it correctly contemplates true suchness;
Second, the profound mind, because it delights in cultivating all good practices;
Third, the mind of great compassion, because it rescues and protects all suffering sentient beings.
The true suchness contemplated is also the fundamental wisdom and fundamental enlightened wisdom, so the latter two aspects manifest as the innumerable inherent qualities.
Moreover, when one of these three minds is present, the other two must also be present, but the three grades of worthies have varying degrees of increase and decrease.
In the ten abodes, the mind of straightforwardness increases, and therefore it is called understanding.
Understanding is the basis of practice and vows, and therefore it is explained first.
